conclusion: The problem involves calculating the work done by the frictional force on an object as it is transported from point M to point N on a conveyor belt.

premise: The object is initially at rest and is subjected to a frictional force due to the conveyor belt. The frictional force is given by F_f = mu mg.
conclusion: The acceleration a of the object is given by a = mu g.

premise: Substituting the given values: mu = 0.3, g = 10 m/s^2.
The object will accelerate until it reaches the speed of the conveyor belt. The time t taken to reach the speed v = 6 m/s is given by v = at.
The distance d traveled by the object during the acceleration phase is given by d = 1/2 at^2.
The total distance between the wheels is L1 = 10 m. After the object reaches the speed of the conveyor belt, it will continue to move at this speed for the remaining distance.
conclusion: The remaining distance is L1 - d = 10 m - 6 m = 4 m.

premise: Since the object is moving at the same speed as the conveyor belt, there is no relative motion and therefore no frictional force acting on the object.
conclusion: The work done by the frictional force during this phase is zero.

premise: The work done by the frictional force is given by W = F_f * d, where d is the distance traveled during the acceleration phase.
conclusion: W = F_f * d = 9 N * 6 m = 54 J
